data.title: Tabs: Various fixes for multiple tabs and right/close buttons position
data.body:
The first commit fixes #4107 which would compute a bad offset due to forgetting about the tab's icons.

The second commit fixes the navigation buttons that were overlapping the tabs when resizing, and used the fixed `get_tab_width` to reduce code duplication.

I'll likely add a third commit just to do some cleanup but no functional change.

data.title: Support for #includes in built-in GL shaders.
data.body: I've added support to the Python script responsible for scanning and exposing the data of the native GLSL into headers to be able to use the #include directive. Since this is a precompiler routine, there are no concerns over driver compatibility, and these additions should also provide protection from recursion or double inclusion. The reason I wanted to add this is thought that if the builtin shaders are going to grow in complexity in the future, it may be an idea to refactor into sets of more managable submodules. Currently, the ubershaders used are quite difficult to follow since composed almost entirely of #ifdefs. In future, I would also like to add similar functionality to user shaders too

data.title: Prompt for unsaved scene changes checks incorrect scene
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 10 Pro x64

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The check to ask for closing the scene in case of unsaved changes checks the currently displayed scene, not the scene which tab is about to be closed.

This creates two issues:
- The current scene has unsaved changes; closing tabs of saved scenes creates a misleading prompt: "Please Confirm...: Close scene? (Unsaved changes will be lost)"
- Even worse: The current scene is saved; closing tabs with unsaved changes does not create a prompt at all and immediately discards the scene and changes.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open multiple scenes, change something in one, try closing the unchanged scenes (or the other way round); you'll get a misleading prompt or none where should be one.

data.title: Support for sending desktop notifications
data.body:
There should be a way to send native notifications for desktop operating systems from Godot. By native notifications, I mean something like this:

![Notification](http://i.imgur.com/UBvoMj9.png)

Those notifications could be sent from the OS singleton, for example. There should probably also be the project icon next to the notification.

`OS.alert()` already exists, but it doesn't send notifications like this, it just makes a blocking pop-up system window.

The main use case of this would be for multiplayer games (be alerted when a new round starts or new chat messages while the window is minimized, for example).

data.title: Resizable text
data.body:
I saw somewhere that this wasn't possible because it's bitmap or something like this. But in Unity, for example, you can resize your text from the text component itself, and don't need to import a new font size each time. 
Maybe if you could adjust it in the label node (or other node that displays text) and then it create the .fnt when compiling. That way you could prototype quickly and it would just import it when necessary (when you actually run the game).

data.title: EventPlayer - shows wrong values for get_loop_count() and get_length()
data.body:
print(get_lenght()) prints 1. 
print(get_loop_count) grows each second ( 1689 and so on).

The song that is played has not looped that many times.
It's lenght in seconds or miliseconds (or whatever that is) is not 1.

It is showing wrong values on both accounts.

Load this IT file in eventPlayer node and see for yourself:
[impulseTrackerFile.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/243541/impulseTrackerFile.zip)

data.title: Implement additional stretch_aspect - crop
data.body:
Please implement an additional stretch aspect mode. Let's call it crop.
If you are familiar with flash, you know what I am talking about - the NO_BORDER scaling mode.

What this will do is scale the content up/down until there are no black borders are appeared. This is like the reverse of what the 'keep' mode is doing in Godot now.
If keep = min(screen_width/game_width,screen_height/game_height),
then crop will be
max(screen_width/game_width,screen_height/game_height)

This will be a best sure way to know that your game won't have any empty areas or black borders on any device without having to test on the device. 

I think that a portrait game should select 'keep_width' and landscape game should select 'keep_height'. I am not sure if this will work perfectly on all devices.

I don't know if there is a way to get the desired appearance without camera zoom. The camera zoom method is a hacky way so that you have to multiply the zoom scale with other elements like canvas layer to get this correct.

data.title: Scaled up CollisionShapes using BoxShapes will flail wildly when colliding.
data.body:
When using the ability to dynamically scale CollisionShapes on RigidBodies, when attempting to scale up a BoxShape, it will intersect and flail wildly with other colliders.

To reproduce this issue, create a RigidBody with a standard box CollisionShape child. Scale the CollisionShape a significant amount (10.0+ should be sufficent) and then place the RigidBody high above a static body to act as the ground. When the RigidBody collides with the ground, it will flail wildy and never stop. This issue only seems to occur with BoxShape colliders; things like SphereShapes and CapsuleShapes do not seem to suffer from the same issue when scaled up.

data.title: C++11 support for linux build - needed to compile creature2d module
data.body:
I've been trying to build godot with support for creature2d. The author of creature 2d has kindly made a module for godot.

it however needs C++11 support. How do I get godot to compile with c++11 support?
https://github.com/kestrelm/Creature_Godot/issues/1

So far I learned that I need to edit the sconstruct file. This however is much too complicated for me. Help much appreciated!

data.title: Platforms: merge isim options in the main iphone platform
data.body: The iSIM platorm (`platform/isim`) is an iOS simulator, which is basically the iOS platform (`platform/iphone`) for x86. It would be nice to try to merge it into the main iOS platform, so that we don't have to register it as a separate platform but could just enable it with a command line switch (e.g. `isim=yes` or `x86=yes`).

data.title: doctool: Homogenise indentation scheme in the XML
data.body:
The various XML tags in the classes.xml template produced by doctool don't have the same expectations regarding the need for indentation.

For example `<description>` expects no additional indentation level:

```
<description>
Return the label used for built-in text.
</description>
```

While `<constant>` expects an indentation:

```
<constant name="NO_INDEX_ARRAY" value="-1">
    Default value used for index_array_len when no indices are present.
</constant>
<constant name="ARRAY_WEIGHTS_SIZE" value="4">
    Amount of weights/bone indices per vertex (always 4).
</constant>
```

Most IDEs seem to increment the indentation level after `<description>`, or at least 90% of the documentation writers add one, which always gets reverted when running doctool again, producing needlessly verbose diffs.

We need to settle on one convention, implement it in doctool and enforce it.

data.title: Need some way to identify collision shapes created using CollisionShape node
data.body:
When using complex 3D setups you basically need to know what part of collision your shape represents. For example, your character can walk, lay on sofa, sit on chair. All these poses (and transitions!) require different collision setups to avoid unwanted behavior. Another example is multi-character animations, where we want to selectively disable collision bodies. Or, entering a car.

To select a body to disable or move you need to identify it. You can loop through bodies in collision object, but you can't identify which is which. Ref<Shape> do not know about names.
one can set names for shapes in GDScript, but not in C++ for some reason. Or do I do something wrong? This is serious issue, basically a show stopper.

data.title: AnimationTreePlayer: oneshot node doesn't work correctly after blend2 node
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
For skeletal animation (transform track).
If we set oneshot node directly into animations, it works as intended, i.e blending one animation into
the other depending on filters. If we set oneshot node main pin into blend2 node,
it never use that animation as basis, it uses default bone pose instead, which looks like zeero channel,
so animation is basically lost for time of oneshot run.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Just setup AnimationTreePlayer, you will bump into this fast enough.
Do transition-blend2-onshot chain, this one was properly tested and always reproduce the bug.
Use transform tracks, or, better, skeletal animation to see the result. I don't care about value tracks
and 2D stuff for this one.

@JoshuaGrams looks like this one is for you :)

data.title: Godot randomly fails to find class members
data.body:
we have several sets of

``` gdscript
const NORMAL = 0
const GRABBED = 1

var state = NORMAL setget switch_state, get_state

func leave_state(st):
    pass
func enter_state(st):
    if st == NORMAL:
        anim.state = anim.STANDING
    elif st == GRABBED:
        anim.state = anim.GRABBED

func switch_state(st):
   if st != state:
       leave_state(state)
       enter_state(st)
   state = st

func get_state():
    return state
```

Some are attached to RigidBody, some are attached to AnimationTreePlayer.

in some instances anim.STANDING, and anim.GRABBED access fails with
Invalid get index 'GRABBED' (on base: 'AnimationTreePlayer (housewife-anim.gd)').
setting these to intended numbers makes things work. Looks like GDScript is very buggy about
constants, it is not first time I meet such behavior, it is not a new thing, it happend with 1.0 too.

No inheritance is used this time, so it fails with just plain GDScript.

Node structure is
RigidBody1 -> script1
+AnimationTreePlayer1 => script3
RigidBody2 => script2
+AnimationTreePlayer2 => script3
The 2nd ATP with script fails to find GRABBED which is directly const, but finds NORMAL.
first ATP have no problems.
